name: Half-Life 2: Episode One
description: Half-Life 2 has sold over 4 million copies worldwide, and earned over 35 Game of the Year Awards. Episode One is the first in a series of games that reveal the aftermath of Half-Life 2 and launch a journey beyond City 17. Also features two multiplayer games. Half-Life 2 not required.
minimum_requirements: 1.7 GHz Processor, 512MB RAM, DirectX® 8.1 level Graphics Card (Requires support for SSE), Windows® 7 (32/64-bit)/Vista/XP, Mouse, Keyboard, Internet Connection Recommended: Pentium 4 processor (3.0GHz, or better), 1GB RAM, DirectX® 9 level Graphics Card, Windows® 7 (32/64-bit)/Vista/XP, Mouse, Keyboard, Internet Connection

reviews.review_text: Some more Half-Life 2.   Continues right where Half-Life 2 left off. A short, yet amazing journey, which involves you, playing as Gordon Freeman, well, er, yeah. I would rather not spoil anything.  It is definitely not going to take you any longer than 5 hours to complete, so I would say it is more than worth dedicating an afternoon to it. The gunplay still feels simply great, exactly like the original game, though I think it is also good to mention that this time, guns are not even required - you can finish the entire game firing only a single bullet. It will not make things any easier, rather obviously the other way around, but if you think you can do it, you can choose to do it.  A must-play for everyone who has played Half-Life 2 before.

Half-Life 2 Episode One is the continuation of the Half-Life saga or rather the story of how Gordon Freeman saved the world. While I was a big fan of the single-player campaign in the original Half-Life these new stories that have been unveiling beginning with with Half-Life 2 just haven't been quite as impressive and Episode One feels much the same way.  The story picks up shortly after the end of Half-Life 2 proper. Through the power of being the protagonist you have somehow manged to survive and must now fight your way out of the city before it implodes on you. There is not much new to the storyline or gameplay and the areas feel like they could have been ripped straight out of the regular Half-Life 2 campaign.  Of course there is a certain bias from me because I never bought Half-Life 2 to play Half-Life 2, that was just a nice little bonus, I bought it for the mods and as such I am not nearly as invested as others in the lives of Alyx and her boytoy Gordon.  Get it if you liked the single-player campaign in Half-Life 2 and want a few more hours of it. Otherwise you can safely ignore it as it's an entirely forgettable expansion.

Pros: +Everything Half Life +Lighting +Character connectedness  Neutral:  *Narrow enviroments *The 'Middle Child' syndrome  Overall: 9/10 If anything, you basically need to play this just to get the amazing Episode Two. As Crab said in his recommendation: 'Nothing happens in this game... I mean really you can skip it.' Of course there is a grain of truth in that statement, when held in the light of Episode 2 or even Half-Life 2, Episode One leaves much to be admired. This can be attributed to the games eco-centric location throughout the ruins of City 17 and the Citadel and the lack of varying companions throughout the game. While doing an excellent job making Alyx seem like a more believable character with well scripted combat sequences and animations you can't help but feel that she's holding your hand through it all. Personally I loved EP1 because the raw urban combat of the final levels of Half-Life 2 were my favorite levels, and Episode One extended on that making for an entire game focused on the best part of HL2. All that being said it's not imperative that you play it, and you can go from HL2 straight to EP2 without worry about missing on vital story points.

I know that a lot of people were disappointed by this installment, but I had a hoot playing it. It's been a secret fantasy of mine to be part of a mass exodus out of a doomed city my whole life. I think my secret desire to make such an escape started with a Fourth of July celebration my parents took me to when I was three. These visions of hundreds of people and shimmering explosions in an unfamiliar urban setting stuck in my tiny baby brain and have been with me my whole life.   So you can imagine my surprise when over a decade later I'm reliving these memories as I flee City 17 in much the same way I imagined myself all those years ago.  This has left me to assume Valve has access to the Jungian archetypes of my mind.

This review contains spoilers regarding Half-Life 2.  Riding on the high octane ending of Half-Life 2 and acting as a direct continuation, Half-Life 2: Episode One manages to be a safe, if not fulfilling, addition to the Half-Life series.  Sticking with the known working formula, in Half-Life 2: Episode One you resume control of Gordon Freeman. Throwing the ending of that game to one side, Gordon finds himself back in City 17 with Alyx and a Citadel on the verge of leveling the entire city. Throughout this episode you venture back into the Citadel to contain the core and then proceed to try and escape City 17 before its destruction.  The issue with this game is it brings very little new to the table. The environments are all rehashes of what was seen in HL2 - the Citadel, the streets and buildings of City 17. The only original feeling portion of the game is where you have to fight through a hospital, constantly being assaulted by Combine and Zombies, with an assault ship opening fire through any window you pass by. Amongst the zombie horde is a new creature: the Zombine. This headcrabbed Combine soldier is stronger and faster than the other zombies, possessing the ability to pull grenades out in a kamikaze run. It spices up the variety little, but only a little, for the most aprt they still act like everything else you've encountered so far. The sections with the Citadel are interesting; now a degenerating and highly unstable building that the Combine are fleeing, but ultimately it's not too indifferent from the final stages of HL2.  The final, and largest, criticism is the length. This game can be completed in roughly five hours. For a game that offers little advancement in plot, instead focusing mainly on combat, there's not a lot here to make it an essential play. Don't get me wrong, it's worth playing if not just to have an excuse to dip back into the HL2 world, but this game struggles to have any sort of re-playability value when HL2 does everything this game does - only better.

Anyways, Episode One is a huge graphical leap from Half Life 2, adding in pretty HDR effects (even though you're going to see a lot of warm colors in this game) and exploring more of the physics based gameplay. One complaint is that it feels pretty short and does feel like you're essentially doing more of the same you did in the last parts of Half Life 2, only in reverse. You also get commentary, which always a great thing to listen to.  Overall, get this game if you played/own Half Life 2 and haven't played Episode one yet

Half-Life 2: Episode One is arguably the worst game in the franchise, right next to Blue Shift. But even though it's not the best in the series, it doesn't mean it's not worth playing.   Pros:  + As always, the gameplay is solid and varied (for the most part) + Excellent voice acting, with all the voice actors from Half-Life 2 returning for their roles here + A new enemy type (yay?) + Updated graphics + Fantastic soundtrack by Kelly Bailey  Neutral:  +- Really short, but it's an episodic game (and it's cheap), so what can you expect  Cons:  - Pacing is kinda off compared to the enjoyable flow of the other games - The order in which you get your guns makes no sense, I mean, the crowbar is one of the last weapons you get, why? - Certain sections are really annoying and tedious Spoilers:    - The last boss is a ♥♥♥♥ing strider (a common powerful enemy) mixed with a boring escort mission      Conclusion: Worth playing, but not a fantastic game by any means.

Half-Life 2: Episode One  Story (8/10):  The story of Half-Life 2: Episode One plays on from the original Half-Life 2. Therefore, in order to fully understand the logic of the story, the original Half-Life 2 should be played. Half-Life 2: Episode One's story spans over five chapters, immersing the player with original characters and enemies. As explained in the Developer's Commentary, there are admittedly some sequences where dialogue is too long and ruins some crucial parts of the story. Although, the story does run well with the five chapters and the ending will possibly leave you wanting the next Episode in the series. Overall, Half-Life 2: Episode One has a good storyline and a few boring non-interactive dialogue moments here and there.  Game play (8/10):  The game play of Half-Life 2: Episode One is fluent and rewarding. Whilst progressing through the storyline, there are pieces of equipment acquired after reaching specific points. These rewards are motivating and is enough to push the player towards the conclusion of the game. Within this game the player will encounter many weapons from the original games, like the iconic crowbar. The combat system in conjunction with weapons is a fluent mix and certain game play mechanics like the flashlight capacity, intensifies certain levels. Also included within the levels is a variety of environmental objects that are interactive and combat effective. These environmental objects are used to create smart solutions to simple problems. In this case, Half-Life 2: Episode One's game play is constructive and destructive, making an enjoyable experience.  Graphics (10/10):  The graphics of Half-Life 2: Episode One is outstanding for it's time. This game has perfect settings for graphic options, from Shader Detail to High Dynamic Range. The lighting and detail of the sprites within the game looks realistic and it immerses the player into the environment. Guns, environmental objects, enemies and everything included looks like real design was incorporated when producing. Explained within the Developer's Commentary, many environment objects were based off real creations and it is reconstructed effectively. In other words, the game developers made the environment look realistic and it is a true accomplishment for the time period for when it was development.  Audio (7/10):  The audio of Half-Life 2: Episode One is realistic but the soundtrack doesn't immerse the player. Whilst playing through the story, combat and exploring situations included music that wasn't exciting enough. Although, the environmental, character, enemy and gun tracks included did give a sense of presence. The sounds when an enemy has acquired a target, a mine has exploded or if a zombie is nearby was executed well. If the player listens closely they can recognise footsteps and the direction of any sound. In conclusion, the games soundtrack is mildly boring but the environmental sounds are good.   Additional Features (8/10):  In Half-Life 2: Episode One there is an additional feature that many previous players of Valve games could recognise, the Developer's Commentary. This feature of the game becomes unlocked once the completion of a desired chapter is registered. The Developer's Commentary provides an inside look on the previous and/or designs, ideas and game play mechanics considered throughout the development of the game. This is encoded using floating speech bubble sprites spread across the five chapters in their appropriate positions. Also, once a commentary is being played, the player becomes invincible to enemy damage and can sometimes freeze the enemies themselves to state an idea. This additional feature is a productive way of expressing the developer's ideas and explaining the nature of the game. After completing the game, it is recommended to try the Developer's Commentary for an in-depth explanation on the games features and aesthetics.   Overall (8.2/10)

Half Life 2: Episode One (SPOILER WARNING)  (Story) Half Life 2: Epsiode One (HL:EP1) picks up where Half Life 2 left off: with a bang. Upon recovering from the influence of the vortigaunts, Alyx and Gordon find themselves at the base of the Citadel. The reactor core, the Citadel's power source, is going critical and it's up to Alyx and Gordon to slow down the meltdown. What follows is a series of events that put Alyx and Gordon at the top of the Combine's list of priorities. As a result, the two must escape the city with their bought time, all the while helping Barney with resistance related business.   (Gameplay) The game is first person with shooting and puzzle solving dominating. There are no vehicular segments in this Episode. For the first half of HL:EP1, pacing is a little slower to allow you to soak in the atmosphere. The dark, underground segments will get your pulse going, especially with the new suicide zombies that run at you with live grenades. The second Half of Episode 1 is more combat focused as you push through the last of City 17's defenders and fight gunships.  (Design) There are several new textures to look at and things all around look a bit sharper coming from Half Life 2. Sound and visual fidelity remain stellar. Lighting is still excellent. Story is well written and paced appropriately. Alyx has several new animations depending on what enemy she is fighting or what weapons she has equipped.   (Final Comments) As the sequel to Half Life 2, HL:EP1 continues the story of Half Life 2, giving us a better understanding of what is happening in City 17. Gordon and Alyx become a dangerous team and the stage is set for Episode 2 very well. Just remember to keep your flashlight charged.

It was all in that moment when I just sat back and laughed. I couldn t believe it was quite this good. I chuckled in muddled disbelief, expectations utterly defied. My nervous fingers reloaded the level, knowing that I had to see that breathtaking sequence one more time. It was then that I knew for certain: Valve had surpassed not only themselves, but everyone else too. Half-Life 2 is an astounding accomplishment. It is the definitive statement of the last five years of first-person shooters. Everything else was just a stopgap.  Half-Life 2 is a near perfect sequel. It takes almost everything that worked from Half-Life and either improves on it, or keeps it much the same. But that simple summation undersells how the Valve team have approached this task. Half-Life 2 is a linear shooter with most of the refinements one would expect from years of work, but it is also a game of a higher order of magnitude than any of the previous pretenders to the throne. The polish and the stratospheric height of the production values mean that Half-Life 2 is a magnificent, dramatic experience that has few peers.  It would be madness for me to spoil this game by talking about the specific turn of events, so spoilers are going to be kept to a minimum. We re going to talk about general processes and the elements of style and design that make Half-Life 2 such an energising experience. Key to this is the way in which Gordon s tale is told. Once again we never leave his perspective. There are no cutscenes, no moment in which you are anything but utterly embedded in Gordon s view of the world. Everything is told through his eyes. And what a story it is. Gordon arrives at the central station at City 17 a disruptive and chilling dystopia. And from there? Well, that would be telling. This is not the contemporary America that Gordon seemed to be living in during the original Half-Life. The events of Black Mesa have affected the whole world. The crossover with Xen has meant that things have altered radically, with hyper-technology existing alongside eastern bloc dereliction.    The world is infested with head-crab zombies and the aliens that were once your enemies now co exist amongst the oppressed masses. This very European city is populated by frightened and desperate American immigrants, and sits under the shadow of a vast, brutalist skyscraper that is consuming the urban sprawl with crawling walls of blue steel. It s a powerful fiction. City 17 is one of the most inventive and evocative game worlds we ve ever seen. The autocratic and vicious behaviour of the masked Overwatch soldiers immediately places you in a high-pressure environment. People look at you with desperate eyes, just waiting for the end to their pain, an end to the power of the mysterious Combine. Who are they? Why are you here? Who are the masterminds behind this tyranny? The questions pile up alongside the bodies.  Half-Life 2 isn t big on exposition, but the clues are there. You re thrust into this frightening near-future reality and just have to deal with it. Your allies are numerous, but they have their own problems. Your only way forward is to help them. And so you do, battling your way along in this relentless, compelling current of violence and action, gradually building up a picture of what has happened since Black Mesa. The Combine, the military government that controls the city in a boot-stamping-face kind of way, are a clear threat, but quite how they came to be and what their purposes are become aching problems. Once again Gordon remains silent, listening to what he is told so that you can find those answers for yourself.  But even with Gordon s vaguely sinister silence (something that is transformed into a subtle joke by the game s characters) there are reams of dialogue in Half-Life 2. It is spoken by bewilderingly talented actors and animated with almost magical precision. Alyx, Eli, Barney and Dr Kleiner are delightful to behold, but they only tell part of the story. There are dozens of other characters, each with their own role to play. And each one is a wondrous creature. They might be blemished, even scarred, with baggy eyes and greasy hair, but you can t tear your eyes away. People, aliens and even crows, have never seemed quite so convincing in a videogame. Doom 3 s lavish monsters are more impressive, but Half-Life 2 s denizens are imbued with life. More importantly, they offer respite. Half-Life 2 s world is a high-bandwidth assault on the senses that seldom lets up. That moment when you see a friendly face is a palpable relief. A moment of safe harbour in a world of ultraviolence. As Gordon travels he is aided by the citizens of City 17 and the underground organisation that aims to fight the oppressors. Their hidden bases are, like the characters who inhabit them, hugely varied an abandoned farm, a lighthouse, a canyon scrapyard and an underground laboratory each superbly realised.    It is this all-encompassing commitment to flawless design that makes Half-Life 2 so appealing. Even without the cascade of inventiveness that makes up the action side of events, the environments become a breathtaking visual menagerie. Cracked slabs and peeling paint, future-graffiti and mossy slate, tufts of wild grass and flaking barrels, shattered concrete and impenetrable tungsten surfaces City 17 and its surrounding landscape make you want to keep exploring, just to see what might be past the next decaying generator or mangled corpse. Whether you find yourself in open, temperate coastline or mired in terrifying technological hellholes, Half-Life 2 presents a perfect face. The first time you see ribbed glass blurring the ominous shape of a soldier on the other side, or any time that you happen to be moving through water, you will see next-generation visuals implemented in a casual, capable manner. Half-Life 2 doesn t have Doom 3 s groundbreaking lighting effects, but objects and characters still have their own real-time shadows and the level design creates a play of light and dark that diminishes anything we ve seen in other games. The very idea that people have actually created this world by hand seems impossible, ludicrous. The detritus in the back of a van, the rubbish that lies in a stairwell it all seems too natural to have come about artificially. Add to this the split-second perfection of the illustrative music, as well as the luscious general soundscape, and you have genuinely mind-boggling beauty.  But these virtual environments are little more than a stage on which the action will play out. And what jaw-dropping, mind-slamming action that is. What s tough to convey in words, or even screenshots, is just how much impact the events of combat confer. This is a joyous, kinetic, action game. The concussive sound effects, combined with the physical solidity of weapons, objects, enemies and environment, make this a shocking experience. Each encounter is lit up with abrupt and impressively brutal effects. Explosions spray shrapnel and sparks, bullets whack and slam with devastating energy. The exploding barrel has never been such a delight. You think that you ve seen exploding barrels before, but no: these impromptu bombs, like everything else in the game, are transformed by the implementation of revelatory object physics. Unlike previous games, the object physics in Half-Life 2 are no longer a visual gimmick they are integral to the action and, indeed, the very plot.  Gordon can pick up anything that isn t bolted down and place, drop or hurl it anywhere you choose. Initially this consists of little more than shifting boxes so that you can climb out of a window, but gradually tasks increase in complexity. Puzzles, ever intuitive, are well signposted and entertaining. If they re tougher than before they re still just another rung up on what you ve already learned. This is immaculate game design. There are a couple of moments in these twenty hours where something isn t perfect in its pace or placing,
